construction_sources: Geographic gaps (P-031 Gulf, India dividend, Japan aging, EU AI Act)
Emerging categories (Coasean shrinkage, hybrid workforce, cascade services)

models.name: Autonomous Drone Swarm Command Platform
models.one_liner: Software platform for orchestrating autonomous drone swarms in ISR and logistics, selling to NATO allies as SaaS-on-SIPR.
models.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle
models.unit_economics: Contract sizes $5-50M/yr per nation. Platform development $15-30M. Gross margin 65-75% once deployed (software + support). Each NATO ally is a separate contract. DoD $13.4B AI line is the initial customer. Ukraine conflict validated swarm tactics.
what_must_be_true: NATO members follow through on 5% GDP defense spending target (Confirmed: 23 of 32 members increased spending 2025)
Autonomous systems allowed in theater without full human-in-loop for each unit (Likely: DoD Replicator program signals acceptance)
Export control regimes permit allied drone software sales (Likely: ITAR reform underway for close allies)
Software-defined swarm architecture proves superior to hardware-heavy alternatives (Uncertain: contested by prime contractors)
models.key_v3_context: P-030 identifies $2.72T global defense spend growing +9.4% real. DoD dedicated $13.4B AI/autonomy line. NATO 5% GDP target by 2035 creates $500B+ annual increase. Ukraine proved autonomous swarms are the defining weapon system. v2 had ZERO defense models because NAICS-by-NAICS scanning missed this cross-cutting military demand.

models.name: Defense AI/ML Intelligence Fusion Platform
models.one_liner: Multi-source intelligence fusion using LLMs to synthesize SIGINT/HUMINT/OSINT/GEOINT into actionable briefs at 100x analyst throughput.
models.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle
models.unit_economics: Annual contracts $10-100M per agency. 5-year IDIQ vehicles typical. Development cost $20-40M (cleared workforce is 60% of cost). Gross margin 45-55% (heavy labor component for cleared engineers). TAM: $8-12B intelligence analytics market growing 15%/yr.
what_must_be_true: LLMs can operate effectively in air-gapped/SCIF environments (Confirmed: Palantir AIP, Microsoft Azure Gov already deployed)
Intelligence community moves from pilot to production AI adoption (Likely: NGA, CIA have active AI strategies)
Security clearance bottleneck manageable for scaling engineering team (Uncertain: 600K+ clearance backlog)
LLM hallucination rates acceptable for intelligence products (Uncertain: requires human verification layer)
models.key_v3_context: Defense intelligence is drowning in data volume (satellite imagery up 40x since 2015, SIGINT volume exponential). AI is not optional — analysts cannot process current collection volume. DoD $13.4B AI line includes intelligence fusion. Five Eyes + NATO creates allied market. v2 missed this because it sits at the intersection of F1 (AI capability) and F3 (geopolitical acceleration) — no single NAICS sector captures it.

models.name: Cybersecurity AI for Defense Networks
models.one_liner: AI-powered network defense and threat hunting platform purpose-built for CMMC 2.0 compliance across the 300K+ Defense Industrial Base.
models.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle
models.unit_economics: SMB DIB contractor: $2-10K/month. Large prime subcontractor: $50-500K/month. 300K+ DIB companies must achieve CMMC 2.0 by 2026-2028. CMMC is a mandate, not optional. Platform cost $5-15M to build. Gross margin 75-85% at scale. TAM: $15-25B (DIB cybersecurity subset of $60.6B cyber market).
what_must_be_true: CMMC 2.0 enforcement proceeds on schedule (Confirmed: final rule published Dec 2024, phased implementation 2025-2028)
300K+ DIB companies actually need to comply vs just large primes (Likely: flow-down requirements to subcontractors)
AI-powered detection materially outperforms rule-based SIEM for defense networks (Confirmed: CrowdStrike, SentinelOne proving in commercial market)
FedRAMP/IL4+ authorization achievable for startup (Uncertain: 12-18 month process, expensive)
models.key_v3_context: CMMC 2.0 mandate creates a hard deadline forcing 300K+ defense contractors to upgrade cybersecurity. This is regulatory-created demand that intersects with F3 (defense spending supercycle) and F5 (fear of cyberattack drives budget). The $60.6B cyber market within the fear economy (F5) has its largest growth vector in defense. v2 had generic cybersecurity models but none targeting the DIB-specific CMMC compliance wedge.

models.name: Defense Logistics AI Optimizer
models.one_liner: AI platform optimizing military supply chain from depot to forward base, reducing logistics tail cost 30-40% across NATO forces.
models.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle
models.unit_economics: Contract sizes $5-30M/yr per military branch/ally. Platform build $10-25M. Gross margin 55-65%. Military logistics is 60-70% of defense budgets by some measures. Every 1% efficiency improvement = billions saved. NATO interoperability creates multi-country market.
what_must_be_true: Military willingness to share supply chain data with AI platform (Likely: Project Overmatch and JADC2 moving in this direction)
Predictive maintenance + demand forecasting AI works for military equipment diversity (Likely: commercial fleet management proves the concept)
NATO standardization sufficient for multi-country platform (Uncertain: STANAG process slow but improving)
Security clearances obtainable for company founders/engineers (Uncertain: bottleneck but manageable with planning)
models.key_v3_context: Military logistics is the unglamorous backbone of defense spending — 60-70% of total defense cost is sustaining forces, not buying weapons. Ukraine exposed critical logistics failures across NATO. F2 (demographics) means fewer soldiers available for logistics roles, forcing automation. The defense AI supercycle (P-030) is not just about weapons — logistics modernization is the largest addressable segment.

models.name: European Defense-Tech AI Platform (AI Act Compliant)
models.one_liner: AI Act-compliant defense AI platform for European NATO members, filling the US defense-tech gap with sovereign European capability.
models.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle + EU AI Act
models.unit_economics: European defense spending up +83% real. EU defense budget proposals $150B+ over 4 years. European governments require sovereign/EU-based vendors for sensitive defense AI. Contract sizes $3-20M/yr. Build cost $15-30M. Gross margin 50-65%. EU-only market but enormous growth trajectory.
what_must_be_true: European rearmament spending materializes as committed (+83% trajectory continues) (Likely: political consensus strong post-Ukraine)
EU AI Act creates meaningful barrier to US defense AI vendors (Likely: data sovereignty + high-risk classification)
European defense procurement modernizes to buy from startups, not just Airbus/Thales/BAE (Uncertain: procurement reform needed)
AI Act exempts or creates clear pathway for defense AI applications (Likely: national security carve-outs expected)
models.key_v3_context: European rearmament is the fastest-accelerating component of P-030 (+83% real). The EU AI Act (F3) creates a regulatory moat that US defense primes cannot easily navigate. European governments increasingly demand sovereign AI capability. This is a GEOGRAPHIC_PLAY that only exists because v3 mapped both P-030 defense supercycle AND EU regulatory divergence simultaneously — v2's NAICS scanning could not see a specifically-European defense AI opportunity.

models.name: Dual-Use Autonomous Vehicle Platform (Defense + Commercial)
models.one_liner: Modular autonomous ground/air vehicle platform selling to defense at cost-plus and to commercial (agriculture, mining) at margin.
models.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle
models.unit_economics: Defense unit price: $200-800K per vehicle (cost-plus contract absorbs R&D). Commercial unit price: $80-300K (agriculture, mining, last-mile). Defense validates technology, commercial generates margin. VC rotation to physical (F4) means capital available. Build cost $30-80M. Gross margin: 25-35% defense, 45-55% commercial.
what_must_be_true: Autonomous ground vehicle technology matures for unstructured environments (Likely: mining/ag autonomy already deployed, defense extends the envelope)
ITAR permits dual-use architecture without compromising defense IP (Uncertain: requires careful architecture from day one)
VC/growth capital available for physical product development at $30-80M scale (Confirmed: F4 capital rotation to hard-tech validated)
Commercial market adopts defense-proven autonomy faster than purpose-built alternatives (Uncertain: commercial may prefer cheaper specialized solutions)
models.key_v3_context: Defense spending (P-030) is the demand anchor, but the real economics come from dual-use. Defense contracts absorb R&D cost and validate technology in hardest environments. Commercial applications (agriculture, mining, warehouse) provide margin. F4 capital rotation to physical means investors are specifically looking for hard-tech with defense demand anchors. v2 had manufacturing/robotics models but none that explicitly leveraged defense demand as the R&D subsidy for commercial autonomy.

models.name: Satellite/Space ISR AI Analytics
models.one_liner: AI platform processing commercial satellite imagery for defense intelligence, change detection, and targeting at 1000x human analyst speed.
models.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle
models.unit_economics: Annual contracts $5-50M per government customer. Commercial satellite data costs dropping (Planet, Maxar, Capella). Platform build $10-20M. Gross margin 70-80% (software analytics on commodity imagery). NRO, NGA, allied intelligence agencies are primary buyers. Growing commercial market (insurance, agriculture, supply chain).
what_must_be_true: Commercial satellite resolution sufficient for military-grade intelligence (Confirmed: 30cm resolution commercially available, SAR at night/clouds)
AI change detection and object recognition reaches military-acceptable accuracy (Likely: >90% accuracy demonstrated in exercises)
Government willingness to use commercial satellite data and commercial AI vendors (Confirmed: NRO Commercial Space Strategy explicitly directs this)
Export control permits sale of analytics (not raw imagery) to allies (Likely: analytics treated differently than raw collection)
models.key_v3_context: Satellite imagery volume is exploding (commercial constellation capacity up 10x in 5 years) but analyst capacity is flat. The intelligence community cannot process what it collects. AI analytics are structurally necessary. NRO explicitly pivoting to commercial satellite integration. This sits at the intersection of F1 (AI vision models) and F3 (defense supercycle + geopolitical ISR demand). v2 missed space/defense entirely.

models.name: Defense Supply Chain Reshoring Enabler
models.one_liner: AI-powered platform matching defense primes with verified domestic/allied-nation suppliers to meet DFARS sourcing requirements.
models.macro_source: P-029 Reshoring Reality Gap + P-030 Defense Supercycle
models.unit_economics: Transaction fee 1-3% on sourced components. Subscription $10-50K/yr for DIB suppliers. Defense procurement is $400B+/yr in US alone. DFARS 252.225-7012 mandates domestic/ally sourcing for many components. Platform build $3-8M. Gross margin 70-80%. Network effect moat: more suppliers = more buyers = more suppliers.
what_must_be_true: Defense reshoring mandates tighten further (Confirmed: China dependency reduction is bipartisan policy)
DIB supply chain remains fragmented enough for marketplace value (Confirmed: 300K+ DIB companies, most are SMBs)
AI supplier matching and verification provides meaningful efficiency gain over manual sourcing (Likely: current process takes months)
Defense primes willing to use third-party platform vs building internal capabilities (Uncertain: large primes may prefer proprietary solutions)
models.key_v3_context: P-029 (reshoring reality gap) meets P-030 (defense supercycle). Defense supply chains are under extreme pressure to re-shore from China/Russia dependencies. But the actual matching of domestic suppliers to defense needs is manual, slow, and broken. The 300K DIB companies need to find each other. This intersection of two patterns was invisible to v2's sector-by-sector approach.

models.name: Autonomous Undersea Systems AI
models.one_liner: AI navigation and mission planning for autonomous undersea vehicles (AUVs) performing ISR, mine clearance, and ASW operations.
models.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle
models.unit_economics: Navy UUV program $3.6B over 5 years. Each AUV mission package $1-5M. AI navigation/mission planning software $5-20M/yr per navy. Build cost $15-30M. Gross margin 50-60%. Market limited to advanced navies (US, UK, Australia, Japan, France). Pacific strategy (AUKUS) is primary demand driver.
what_must_be_true: Autonomous undersea navigation AI reaches reliability threshold for uncrewed multi-day operations (Uncertain: GPS-denied environment is extremely challenging)
Navy procurement pipeline moves from prototype to production (Likely: Orca XLUUV in production, but slow)
AUKUS framework enables allied undersea tech sharing (Likely: pillar 2 explicitly includes undersea capabilities)
Commercial applications (pipeline inspection, seabed mining) create secondary market (Uncertain: commercial UUV market small)
models.key_v3_context: The Pacific strategic competition (F3 geopolitics) makes undersea capability a top priority. AUKUS specifically targets autonomous undersea systems. Submarines take 10+ years to build; autonomous UUVs can be deployed in 2-3 years. This is the asymmetric counter to China's naval buildup. However, technical uncertainty in GPS-denied autonomous navigation keeps this as CONDITIONAL.

models.name: Defense Predictive Maintenance AI
models.one_liner: AI-powered predictive maintenance for military vehicles, aircraft, and ships, reducing downtime 40% and maintenance costs 25%.
models.macro_source: P-030 Defense AI Supercycle
models.unit_economics: Military equipment readiness rates are 55-72% (target >80%). Each 1% improvement in F-35 availability saves $500M+/yr. Contract sizes $3-20M/yr per platform type. Platform build $8-15M. Gross margin 65-75%. Total DoD maintenance spend ~$90B/yr. Even 5% AI-driven efficiency = $4.5B addressable.
what_must_be_true: Military platforms generate sufficient sensor data for AI prediction (Confirmed: modern platforms have 1000+ sensors, legacy being retrofitted)
AI predictive models trained on military equipment failure data outperform scheduled maintenance (Likely: commercial fleet management proves 30-50% improvement)
DoD data sharing policies permit AI vendor access to maintenance records (Uncertain: data classification varies by platform)
Military maintenance workforce accepts AI augmentation (Likely: F2 demographics means not enough maintenance personnel — AI is necessity not luxury)
models.key_v3_context: Military readiness is the peacetime metric that matters most, and it is chronically below target. Maintenance is 30-40% of lifecycle defense cost. F2 demographics means maintenance workforce is aging and shrinking. F1 AI capability can predict failures before they happen. The $90B/yr DoD maintenance budget is one of the largest single-customer addressable markets in the world. v2 had commercial predictive maintenance models but none targeting the defense-specific readiness problem.

models.name: AI Adaptive Tutoring Engine (K-12)
models.one_liner: AI tutoring platform delivering personalized 1-on-1 instruction at $20/mo vs $50-80/hr human tutors, targeting 50M+ US K-12 students.
models.macro_source: Education Baumol Cure + F2 Teacher Shortage
models.unit_economics: Consumer price $15-30/mo (vs $200-400/mo for human tutoring). AI inference cost $0.50-2.00/student/month. Gross margin 85-90%. 50M US K-12 students, 15-20% addressable immediately (families spending on supplemental education). Jevons multiplier 5-10x: at $20/mo, families who never could afford tutoring enter the market. TAM: $12-20B US, $80-120B global.
what_must_be_true: AI tutoring produces measurable learning outcome improvements (Likely: early evidence from Khan Academy Khanmigo shows 1.2 sigma improvement in pilots)
Parents willing to pay $15-30/mo for AI tutoring (Confirmed: 80M+ existing educational app subscriptions globally)
55% student discomfort with AI-in-education can be overcome through design (Uncertain: F5 psychology is the primary friction)
AI tutors handle pedagogical nuance beyond drill-and-practice (Likely: LLM Socratic method demonstrated but not proven at scale)
models.key_v3_context: Education is the largest Baumol-affected sector globally ($1T+) with costs rising +5%/yr for decades. 42 states face teacher shortages (F2). AI inference at $0.40/M tokens makes personalized tutoring economically trivial. But F5 (psychology) creates a 55% discomfort barrier that is the highest of any sector. The business model must design around fear, not ignore it. v2 had one thin education model; this is the sector's structural necessity model.

models.name: Teacher Augmentation Platform (Admin + Lesson Prep)
models.one_liner: AI platform eliminating 60% of teacher administrative burden (grading, IEPs, lesson plans, parent comms) to retain burnt-out teachers.
models.macro_source: F2 Teacher Pipeline Collapse
models.unit_economics: School district contract: $3-8/student/yr (3.5M teachers across 130K schools). Teacher time saved: 10-15 hrs/week on admin tasks. Retention improvement: even 5% reduction in attrition saves districts $15K-30K per retained teacher. Platform build $3-8M. Gross margin 80-85%. TAM: $5-12B US, $20-40B global. The customer is the district, not the teacher.
what_must_be_true: Teacher administrative burden is genuinely 40-60% of work time (Confirmed: multiple studies, RAND 2024)
AI-generated lesson plans and IEPs meet quality standards for educational compliance (Likely: template-based compliance work is well-suited to AI)
School districts have budget authority for AI tools (Uncertain: budget cycles slow, ESSER funding expired 2024)
Teachers adopt rather than resist AI tools (Likely when positioned as admin relief, not teaching replacement — critical framing)
models.key_v3_context: The teacher shortage (42 states, F2) is not primarily a compensation problem — it is a burnout problem. Teachers spend 40-60% of time on non-teaching administrative work. AI can eliminate most of this burden, making the job sustainable. This is TEACHER AUGMENTATION, not replacement — a critical distinction given the 55% student discomfort (F5). v2 missed this because sector scanning saw 'education' as a single category rather than decomposing the teacher productivity crisis from the student learning opportunity.

models.name: Alternative Credential Verification Network
models.one_liner: Blockchain-anchored credential verification for AI-era skills, replacing degree signaling with demonstrated competency proof.
models.macro_source: Education Structural Shift + F4 Capital Rotation
models.unit_economics: Verification fee $5-15 per credential check. Credential issuance $50-200 per learner per skill. Network of employers + training providers + learners. $500M-$2B market in 3-5 years. Platform build $2-5M. Gross margin 75-85%. Network effects: more employers accepting = more learners pursuing = more issuers joining.
what_must_be_true: Employers meaningfully reduce degree requirements in favor of demonstrated skills (Likely: Google, Apple, IBM already dropped degree requirements, 45% of LinkedIn jobs dropped degree req 2023-2025)
AI-era skills change fast enough that traditional degrees cannot keep up (Confirmed: 39% of skills obsolete within 5 years per WEF)
Credential fraud/inflation doesn't undermine trust in new system (Uncertain: same problem that plagues current system)
Network reaches critical mass of both employers and credential issuers (Uncertain: classic chicken-and-egg marketplace problem)
models.key_v3_context: The 39% skills obsolescence rate (WEF) means traditional 4-year degrees are structurally mismatched with employer needs. The AI transformation is accelerating this mismatch. But the current credential system (degrees, certifications) has no mechanism for rapid skill verification in new domains (prompt engineering, AI ops, human-AI collaboration). This is an emerging category that does not map cleanly to any NAICS code — v2 could not detect it.

models.name: Corporate AI Reskilling-as-a-Service
models.one_liner: Enterprise platform diagnosing workforce AI skill gaps, delivering personalized reskilling programs, and measuring productivity uplift.
models.macro_source: F1 AI Adoption Gap + F2 Workforce Pipeline
models.unit_economics: Enterprise license $50-200/employee/yr. Average enterprise deal $500K-$5M/yr. 59% of workers say they won't get adequate AI training (WEF). 39% of skills obsolete within 5 years. Fortune 500 L&D budgets $1-10M/yr on AI reskilling. Platform build $5-12M. Gross margin 75-85%. TAM: $30-50B corporate training market, AI reskilling capturing 20-30% share.
what_must_be_true: Corporations invest in reskilling rather than replacing workforce (Likely: reputational risk + institutional knowledge loss incentivize retention)
AI-powered skill diagnostics are meaningfully better than survey-based assessment (Likely: AI can test actual capability, not self-reported comfort)
Measurable productivity uplift can be attributed to reskilling program (Uncertain: attribution is hard in complex organizations)
59% training gap is a budget problem, not a willingness problem (Uncertain: some employees resist reskilling)
models.key_v3_context: 39% of skills obsolete in 5 years. 59% of workers say they won't get adequate training. This is a STRUCTURAL gap between AI capability advancement (F1 accelerating) and workforce adaptation. Corporations face a choice: reskill or replace. Most will try to reskill first (cheaper, less disruptive, better optics). The 78-point manufacturing implementation gap (98% exploring, 20% ready) proves the problem extends beyond white-collar. v2 had no dedicated corporate reskilling model despite it being a $30-50B market.

models.name: India AI Workforce Academy
models.one_liner: AI-native training platform producing 500K+ AI-skilled workers/yr for India's 12M annual workforce entrants at $50-200/course.
models.macro_source: India Demographic Dividend + F1 AI Demand
models.unit_economics: Course price $50-200 (adjusted for India purchasing power). 12M annual workforce entrants, 70% have skills gap. Even 5% market capture = 420K learners/yr = $21-84M revenue. AI delivery cost $1-5/learner/course. Gross margin 90%+. Platform build $2-5M. Employer-paid tier at $500-2000/employee adds B2B revenue layer.
what_must_be_true: India's demographic dividend translates to actual AI job demand (Likely: India IT services sector $250B+, needs AI transformation)
Mobile-first AI education delivery works for India's infrastructure (Confirmed: India has 800M+ smartphone users, Byju's proved mobile ed-tech model)
Willingness to pay $50-200 for vocational AI training (Likely: premium for AI skills over general IT training demonstrated in India)
Employer recognition of AI academy credentials (Uncertain: requires employer partnerships from launch)
models.key_v3_context: India has 1.44B population, median age 28, 12M annual workforce entrants (F2 demographic dividend). 70% have an AI skills gap. India's IT services sector ($250B+) faces existential pressure to upskill from traditional coding to AI engineering. At $0.40/M token inference, delivering AI-powered education at India price points is finally economically viable. v2 had no India-specific education model despite India being the world's largest education market by student volume.

models.name: AI-Powered Special Education Services Platform
models.one_liner: AI augmentation for special education professionals delivering IEP compliance, behavior tracking, and adaptive instruction for 7.5M US students.
models.macro_source: F2 Special Ed Workforce Crisis + Education Baumol
models.unit_economics: District contract $100-300/student/yr for 7.5M US special ed students. Special ed spending $120B+/yr in US. 50% of districts report special ed teacher shortages. AI reduces IEP documentation time 50-70%, freeing teachers for direct student interaction. Platform build $3-8M. Gross margin 80%. Federal mandate (IDEA) ensures demand regardless of budget pressure.
what_must_be_true: AI-generated IEPs and progress reports meet legal compliance standards (Uncertain: high-stakes legal documents, but template-driven format suited to AI)
Special education professionals adopt AI tools (Likely: severe understaffing creates necessity over resistance)
Federal funding for special education remains stable (Confirmed: IDEA is a federal mandate, funding has only increased)
Parents of special needs children accept AI involvement (Uncertain: F5 psychology highest in this population)
models.key_v3_context: Special education has the most acute version of the education workforce crisis (F2) — 50% of districts cannot fill special ed positions. IDEA federal mandate means services MUST be delivered regardless of staffing. IEP documentation consumes 40-60% of special ed teacher time. AI can automate compliance documentation while freeing professionals for direct student work. This is invisible in NAICS scanning because special ed is buried within broader education codes.

models.name: Trades and Technical Skills AI Simulator
models.one_liner: AI + VR training platform for skilled trades (electrical, plumbing, HVAC) compressing 4-year apprenticeships to 18-24 months.
models.macro_source: F2 Trades Shortage (499K workers needed)
models.unit_economics: Training program $2-5K/apprentice (vs $15-30K for traditional 4-year apprenticeship when including opportunity cost). 499K new workers needed in building trades by 2026. Union training programs and community colleges as channel partners. VR hardware $300-500/unit. AI tutoring cost $5-15/student/month. Platform build $5-10M. Gross margin 70-80%.
what_must_be_true: AI + VR simulation meaningfully compresses time-to-competency for manual trades (Uncertain: some skills require physical practice that simulation cannot fully replace)
Union apprenticeship programs adopt AI-augmented training (Uncertain: union culture may resist shortening apprenticeships)
Regulatory bodies accept compressed apprenticeship timelines (Uncertain: licensing requirements vary by state and trade)
Employer demand for faster workforce pipeline overcomes institutional resistance (Likely: 499K shortage creates desperation)
models.key_v3_context: 499K workers needed in building trades (F2) with data center construction (F6) adding massive new demand. Traditional 4-year apprenticeships cannot scale fast enough. AI-powered simulation could compress training while maintaining quality. The trades shortage intersects with energy infrastructure demand (data centers need electricians) in a way that v2's separate sector scanning could not detect.

models.name: AI Governance and Compliance Operating System
models.one_liner: Enterprise platform managing AI model inventory, risk assessment, bias monitoring, and regulatory compliance across US/EU/China regimes.
models.macro_source: F5 Fear Economy + EU AI Act
models.unit_economics: Enterprise subscription $100K-$2M/yr based on AI model count and risk level. AI governance market: $309M (2024) -> $15.8B (2030) = 51x growth. EU AI Act mandates compliance by Aug 2026 for high-risk systems. Every Fortune 500 company deploying AI needs this. Platform build $5-12M. Gross margin 80-85%. TAM: $15.8B and growing.
what_must_be_true: EU AI Act enforcement proceeds on schedule with meaningful penalties (Confirmed: final rules published, 2-4% global revenue penalties)
US adopts some form of AI governance framework (Likely: sector-specific rules emerging, NIST AI RMF as baseline)
Enterprises cannot build governance tools internally fast enough (Likely: specialized domain, changing regulations)
AI governance becomes a C-suite priority, not just a compliance checkbox (Likely: board-level AI risk discussions increasing)
models.key_v3_context: The $86B fear economy (F5) has its most structured component in AI governance ($309M -> $15.8B = 51x). EU AI Act creates a HARD DEADLINE (Aug 2026) for compliance. Three diverging regulatory regimes (US, EU, China) make cross-jurisdictional compliance complex and valuable. This is fear-as-market-creator: the 46% adoption plateau and enterprise caution DRIVE demand for governance tools. v2 had one governance model (MC-52-003) in financial services only — this is the horizontal, cross-sector version.

models.name: Human-Created Content Authenticity Platform
models.one_liner: Provenance verification system proving content was human-created, serving publishers, brands, and creators seeking a 'human premium' mark.
models.macro_source: F5 Fear Economy + Human Premium Signal
models.unit_economics: Publisher subscription $500-5000/mo for verification API. Creator verification $5-15/piece. Brand partnership for verified human content $10-50K/campaign. 23% willing to pay 15-20% premium for human services. Content authenticity market projected $3-8B by 2030. Platform build $2-5M. Gross margin 80-85%.
what_must_be_true: Consumer demand for human-created content persists and grows (Likely: 23% premium willingness already measured, similar to organic food trajectory)
Technical ability to reliably distinguish human vs AI content remains possible (Uncertain: adversarial AI generation may defeat detection)
Provenance-based approach (tracking creation process) is more reliable than detection (Likely: C2PA standard gaining adoption)
Major platforms adopt content provenance standards (Likely: Google, Adobe, Microsoft all in C2PA coalition)
models.key_v3_context: F5 psychology reveals 23% willingness to pay 15-20% premium for human services — analogous to organic food movement (started at similar levels, now $63B US market). AI content flood makes provenance verification structurally necessary for publishers, brands, and creators. This is a new market category created entirely by fear/uncertainty around AI content. v2 could not detect this because it requires the F5 psychology framework — sector scanning has no mechanism to identify fear-created demand.

models.name: AI Safety Audit and Red Team Service
models.one_liner: Third-party AI safety audit firm providing red-teaming, bias testing, and safety certification for enterprise AI deployments.
models.macro_source: F5 Fear Economy + Regulatory Demand
models.unit_economics: Audit engagement $50-500K per AI system. Red team exercise $25-150K. Annual retainer $200K-$2M for continuous monitoring. AI safety market $9.8B by 2030. Requires specialized talent (AI researchers + domain experts) but low capex. Build cost $1-3M (primarily talent acquisition). Gross margin 60-70% (labor-intensive). CE score high because capital-light, cash-flow positive early.
what_must_be_true: AI safety audits become mandated or standard practice (Likely: EU AI Act mandates for high-risk, US sector regulators following)
Third-party audit provides value vs internal testing (Likely: same logic as financial audits — independence matters)
Talent supply sufficient to scale audit capacity (Uncertain: AI safety researchers are scarce)
Audit methodologies standardize enough for repeatable service delivery (Likely: NIST AI RMF and ISO/IEC 42001 providing frameworks)
models.key_v3_context: The $9.8B AI safety market is the second leg of the fear economy tripod (governance + safety + cyber). EU AI Act mandates third-party conformity assessments for high-risk AI systems. This is analogous to the creation of the financial audit industry — regulation creating a mandatory professional service. v2 had no safety audit models because the market barely existed until regulatory mandates crystallized in 2025-2026.

models.name: AI Insurance and Liability Products
models.sector_name: Direct Property and Casualty Insurance (AI Liability)
models.one_liner: Insurance products covering AI system failures, bias liability, and autonomous system accidents for enterprises deploying AI at scale.
models.macro_source: F5 Fear Economy + AI Deployment Scale
models.unit_economics: Policy premium $10-500K/yr based on AI risk profile. Loss ratio targets 50-65%. 295 FDA-cleared AI medical devices, thousands of enterprise AI deployments, autonomous vehicles, drone operations — all need coverage. No major insurer has dedicated AI liability product line. Underwriting requires AI expertise most insurers lack. MGA model: $2-5M to launch, use reinsurance capacity. TAM: $5-15B by 2030.
what_must_be_true: AI-specific liability legal framework develops (Likely: EU AI Liability Directive adopted, US tort law adapting)
Actuarial models can price AI risk without decades of loss history (Uncertain: novel risk category, limited claims data)
Enterprises prefer insurance to self-insuring AI risk (Likely: board/CFO risk aversion drives demand)
Reinsurance capacity available for AI risk (Likely: major reinsurers exploring AI risk portfolios)
models.key_v3_context: Every enterprise deploying AI at scale faces liability questions that current insurance products don't cover. Who is liable when an AI medical device misdiagnoses? When an autonomous drone injures someone? When an AI hiring tool discriminates? The EU AI Liability Directive explicitly creates new liability frameworks. This is a fear-economy product: demand is driven by fear of AI failure, not by AI success. The insurance industry's own disruption (MC-52 models) creates both the expertise gap and the opportunity.

models.name: Trust-Bridging Human-AI Handoff Service
models.one_liner: Managed service ensuring seamless human-AI handoff in high-stakes interactions (healthcare, legal, finance), reducing adoption friction.
models.macro_source: F5 Fear Economy + Adoption Plateau
models.unit_economics: Enterprise service contract $100K-$1M/yr. Manages the human-AI transition for customer-facing processes. Healthcare: patient-to-AI triage, then human handoff. Legal: AI document prep, attorney review. Finance: AI recommendation, advisor confirmation. Revenue: per-interaction fee or subscription. Platform build $3-8M. Gross margin 65-75%. TAM: $5-10B (subset of $86B fear economy focused on adoption bridging).
what_must_be_true: 46% adoption plateau is caused by trust/handoff friction, not technology limits (Likely: F5 analysis confirms psychology is the binding constraint)
Managed human-AI handoff measurably improves adoption rates (Uncertain: limited evidence for managed transition services)
Enterprises outsource trust engineering rather than building internally (Uncertain: large enterprises may prefer internal solutions)
Trust-bridging service becomes standard practice for regulated industry AI deployment (Likely: regulatory pressure for human oversight mandates it)
models.key_v3_context: The 46% adoption plateau (F5) represents the single largest commercial opportunity hidden in plain sight: breaking through psychology barriers to unlock the remaining 54% of the market. The healthcare trust gap (34 points) and education discomfort (55%) are not technology problems — they are trust engineering problems. The 'invisible AI pathway' (P-032) in healthcare proves that adoption succeeds when the human-AI handoff is well-designed. v2 could not see this because it requires the F5 psychology framework.

models.name: Deepfake Detection and Digital Identity Shield
models.one_liner: Real-time deepfake detection for enterprise video calls, authentication, and media verification protecting against AI-generated fraud.
models.macro_source: F5 Fear Economy + AI Fraud Vector
models.unit_economics: Enterprise API: $0.01-0.10/verification call. Enterprise platform: $5-50K/month. Consumer product: $5-15/month. Deepfake fraud losses projected $40B+ by 2027. CEO impersonation via deepfake already causing millions in losses per incident. Platform build $3-8M. Gross margin 80-85%. TAM: subset of $60.6B cybersecurity market, deepfake-specific $3-8B by 2028.
what_must_be_true: Deepfake detection technology stays ahead of generation technology (Uncertain: adversarial arms race, but detection has structural advantages in enterprise-controlled environments)
Enterprise deepfake fraud becomes common enough to drive security spending (Confirmed: $25M Hong Kong deepfake CEO fraud, FBI warnings, 3000% increase in deepfake attempts 2023-2025)
Real-time detection achievable without unacceptable latency (Likely: current models achieve <200ms for video, <50ms for audio)
Regulatory requirement for deepfake detection in financial/legal proceedings (Likely: emerging in multiple jurisdictions)
models.key_v3_context: AI-generated deepfakes represent the fastest-growing fraud vector. F5 fear of AI is partially driven by deepfake proliferation. The cybersecurity component of the fear economy ($60.6B) includes deepfake defense as a rapidly growing segment. This is a pure fear-economy product: AI capability (F1) creates the threat, and fear (F5) creates the demand for defense. The arms race dynamic is real but enterprise environments (controlled cameras, known participants) favor detection.

models.name: AI Watermarking and Model Provenance Registry
models.one_liner: Universal AI output watermarking and model lineage tracking system, enabling regulatory compliance and content attribution at scale.
models.macro_source: F5 Fear Economy + EU AI Act Mandate
models.unit_economics: API pricing: $0.001-0.01/watermarked output. Enterprise license $50-500K/yr. Model providers (OpenAI, Google, Meta, Anthropic) pay for watermarking infrastructure. Media companies pay for detection. EU AI Act requires AI output labeling for high-risk systems. Platform build $3-8M. Gross margin 85-90%. TAM: $2-5B by 2030 (subset of governance market).
what_must_be_true: Technical watermarking that survives modification becomes reliable (Uncertain: active research area, some approaches demonstrated but not at scale)
Regulation mandates AI output watermarking (Likely: EU AI Act Article 50 requires labeling, US executive order signals similar direction)
Model providers adopt standardized watermarking rather than proprietary approaches (Uncertain: competitive dynamics may resist standardization)
Consumer/enterprise demand for provenance tracking is sufficient to create market (Likely: content attribution disputes increasing exponentially)
models.key_v3_context: EU AI Act Article 50 requires that AI-generated content be labeled. This is a regulatory mandate creating a new infrastructure layer. C2PA and other standards are emerging but no dominant platform exists. The model provenance problem (which model generated which output, with what training data) is increasingly important for liability and compliance. This is infrastructure for the fear economy — not a direct fear product, but the plumbing that governance, safety, and compliance products need.

models.name: Grid Interconnection Consulting and Expediting Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered platform streamlining the 5+ year grid interconnection queue for data centers, solar, wind, and battery projects.
models.macro_source: F6 Energy Grid Bottleneck (2,600 GW queue)
models.unit_economics: Consulting engagement $50-500K per project. Success fee 0.5-2% of project value on interconnection approval. 2,600 GW in queue = thousands of projects waiting. Average project value $50-500M. Platform reduces study timelines 30-50% via AI engineering analysis. Build cost $2-5M. Gross margin 70-80%. TAM: $3-8B/yr (interconnection services market).
what_must_be_true: Grid interconnection queue remains the binding constraint (Confirmed: 2,600 GW backlog, FERC Order 2023 reform insufficient to clear)
AI can meaningfully accelerate engineering studies and grid modeling (Likely: computational power increase + AI optimization reduces 12-18 month studies to 3-6 months)
Project developers willing to pay premium for queue acceleration (Confirmed: $50M+ solar projects losing millions per month in delayed revenue)
Regulatory framework permits third-party interconnection analysis (Likely: ISOs/RTOs increasingly accepting third-party studies)
models.key_v3_context: The 2,600 GW interconnection queue is THE binding constraint on AI scaling, renewable energy deployment, and data center expansion. Projects wait 5+ years for grid connection. This is a $3-8B/yr service market created entirely by the F6 energy bottleneck. Every data center, every solar farm, every battery storage project needs interconnection. v2 had no energy infrastructure models because sector scanning saw utilities as a regulated sector with low disruption potential — missing the massive service market created by the bottleneck itself.

models.name: Behind-the-Meter Power for Data Centers
models.one_liner: Develop and operate behind-the-meter gas/solar/battery power plants co-located with data centers, bypassing the 5-year grid queue.
models.macro_source: F6 Grid Bottleneck + F1 AI Compute Demand
models.unit_economics: PPA at $0.06-0.10/kWh (vs grid at $0.08-0.15/kWh with interconnection risk). 100MW data center uses ~$50-80M/yr in electricity. Development cost $50-200M per installation (gas turbine + solar + battery). Project finance available at 6-8%. IRR target 12-18%. Data centers at 4%+ of grid, projected 6-12% by 2030 — cannot wait for grid queue.
what_must_be_true: Grid interconnection queue remains bottlenecked for 3+ years (Confirmed: structural issue, not temporary)
Data center operators accept behind-the-meter power over grid power (Confirmed: Amazon, Microsoft, Google all pursuing direct power procurement)
Permitting for gas/solar co-located with data centers is faster than grid interconnection (Likely: behind-the-meter avoids ISO queue)
Capital available for project finance at $50-200M scale (Confirmed: F4 capital rotation to physical infrastructure)
models.key_v3_context: AI compute demand (F1) requires electricity that the grid cannot deliver (F6 bottleneck). The solution is to bring power generation TO the data center rather than connecting data centers to the grid. This is a capital-intensive but structurally necessary infrastructure play. F4 capital rotation means project finance is available. Microsoft/Amazon/Google are already doing this at scale — the opportunity is serving the hundreds of smaller data center operators who need the same solution.

models.name: Nuclear Site Development and Licensing Services
models.one_liner: End-to-end nuclear site development services for AI companies and utilities pursuing SMR and legacy restart for AI baseload power.
models.macro_source: F6 Nuclear Renaissance + AI Baseload Demand
models.unit_economics: Site assessment: $500K-$2M. NRC licensing support: $5-20M over 3-5 year process. Construction management: 5-10% of project cost ($500M-$2B per reactor). 10GW+ committed for AI (TMI restart, Kairos SMR, Talen). Each GW = $3-8B investment. TAM: $5-15B in nuclear services over next decade. Build cost $3-8M (specialized talent acquisition). Gross margin 50-65% (engineering labor intensive).
what_must_be_true: Nuclear renaissance materializes beyond announcements (Likely: TMI restart contract signed with Microsoft, NRC applications submitted for multiple SMRs)
NRC licensing timeline is manageable (Uncertain: NRC review process historically takes 3-5 years, understaffed for SMR reviews)
Public acceptance of nuclear doesn't reverse (Uncertain: NIMBY risk at specific sites, but overall sentiment improving)
AI companies maintain commitment to nuclear baseload (Likely: 24/7 compute requires 24/7 power, nuclear is the only zero-carbon baseload option)
models.key_v3_context: The nuclear renaissance is driven by AI baseload demand (F1 + F6 intersection). Data centers need 24/7 power that solar/wind cannot reliably provide. 10GW+ of nuclear is committed for AI. But nuclear development requires specialized services — site selection, NRC licensing, community engagement, construction management — that the atrophied nuclear workforce cannot supply. The nuclear supply chain was dismantled over 30 years and must be rebuilt. v2 had no nuclear models because sector scanning saw nuclear as a mature/declining industry — missing the AI-driven restart.

models.name: Utility-Scale Battery Storage Deployment Platform
models.one_liner: Software platform + deployment service for utility-scale battery storage, optimizing siting, procurement, interconnection, and dispatch.
models.macro_source: F6 Grid Bottleneck + Battery Cost Decline
models.unit_economics: Software platform fee: 1-3% of project value for deployment optimization. Dispatch optimization: $2-5/kW/yr recurring. Battery costs at $115/kWh dropping to $80/kWh by 2027. Lithium surplus through 2027 keeps costs low. US battery storage deployments projected 100GW+ by 2030. Each GW = $300-500M installed. TAM: $3-8B/yr in deployment services.
what_must_be_true: Battery cost trajectory continues downward to $80/kWh by 2027 (Confirmed: lithium surplus, manufacturing scale increasing)
Grid bottleneck drives demand for distributed storage as grid stabilization (Confirmed: FERC Order 2222 enables storage participation in wholesale markets)
AI optimization of battery dispatch meaningfully improves economics (Likely: 10-20% revenue improvement from better charge/discharge optimization)
Supply chain for lithium-iron-phosphate cells remains robust (Likely: lithium surplus, LFP manufacturing scale in China + emerging US)
models.key_v3_context: Battery storage is the complement to the grid bottleneck (F6). As grid interconnection queues lengthen, distributed storage becomes more valuable — both for renewable energy time-shifting and for grid stabilization. Battery costs dropping 30% over 3 years (F6) while capital rotates to physical infrastructure (F4). The deployment challenge is the bottleneck: site selection, permitting, interconnection, operations optimization. AI can compress this from 3-5 years to 1-2 years.

models.name: Industrial Energy Efficiency AI
models.one_liner: AI platform reducing industrial energy consumption 15-30% through real-time process optimization, targeting $200B+ US industrial energy spend.
models.macro_source: F6 Energy Constraint + F1 AI Optimization
models.unit_economics: Shared savings model: 20-40% of energy reduction as fee. Average industrial facility $1-10M/yr energy cost, 15-30% reduction = $150K-$3M savings/yr. Platform fee = $30K-$1.2M/yr per facility. 350K manufacturing establishments in US. Platform build $5-10M. Gross margin 75-85%. Payback period for customer: 3-9 months.
what_must_be_true: Industrial process optimization via AI achieves 15-30% energy reduction (Confirmed: Google achieved 40% cooling energy reduction in data centers, industrial pilots showing 10-25%)
Industrial facilities have sufficient sensor/SCADA data for AI optimization (Likely: most medium-large facilities have data, small facilities may need sensor retrofit)
Energy prices remain high enough to justify investment (Confirmed: F6 grid bottleneck keeps energy expensive)
Industrial operators adopt AI-controlled process adjustments (Uncertain: control system changes in industrial environments require safety validation)
models.key_v3_context: F6 energy constraint means electricity is getting MORE expensive and less available. Industrial energy efficiency becomes more valuable as costs rise. AI optimization of industrial processes has proven 15-40% reduction in controlled settings. $200B+ US industrial energy spend means even modest penetration creates a large market. This is a Jevons paradox play: AI makes energy use more efficient, which makes MORE industrial production viable, expanding the market.

models.name: Critical Minerals AI Supply Chain Platform
models.one_liner: AI platform for critical mineral (copper, lithium, rare earths) supply chain visibility, alternative sourcing, and recycling optimization.
models.macro_source: F6 Energy Transition + F3 Geopolitical Supply Risk
models.unit_economics: Platform subscription $100K-$1M/yr for OEMs, mining companies, and battery manufacturers. Transaction facilitation fee 0.5-2% on sourced minerals. Copper deficit projected 5-10M tons by 2030. Rare earth dependency on China 60-70%. AI optimizes exploration targeting, processing efficiency, and urban mining/recycling. Build cost $5-10M. Gross margin 70-80%. TAM: $5-15B in mineral supply chain services.
what_must_be_true: Critical mineral shortages materialize as projected (Confirmed: copper deficit growing, IEA projects 2-3x demand growth for energy transition minerals)
AI meaningfully improves mineral exploration and processing efficiency (Likely: AI geological analysis reducing exploration costs 30-50% in pilots)
Geopolitical pressure drives reshoring of mineral supply chains (Confirmed: US critical minerals strategy, EU Critical Raw Materials Act, India mineral subsidies)
Recycling/urban mining becomes economically viable at scale (Uncertain: technology improving but still 2-5x more expensive than primary mining for most minerals)
models.key_v3_context: The energy transition (F6) requires massive mineral inputs — copper, lithium, cobalt, rare earths, nickel. China controls 60-70% of rare earth processing (F3 geopolitical risk). The grid bottleneck (2,600 GW in queue) means 2,600 GW of copper, steel, and rare earths needed. AI can optimize the entire supply chain from exploration to recycling. v2 had no mineral supply chain models because mining was never scanned as a sector — it only becomes visible when you trace the F6 energy constraint to its material inputs.

models.name: Data Center Cooling and Water Efficiency AI
models.one_liner: AI-optimized liquid cooling systems for AI data centers, reducing water consumption 60-80% and energy use 30-40% vs air cooling.
models.macro_source: F6 Data Center Energy + Water Stress
models.unit_economics: Liquid cooling system: $2-5M per MW of data center capacity. AI optimization software: $50-200K/yr per data center. GPU density requires liquid cooling — air cooling cannot handle 1000W+ GPU racks. 1.7B gallons/day data center water consumption globally. Build cost $10-20M (hardware + software). Gross margin: 35-45% hardware, 80% software. TAM: $15-25B data center cooling market, liquid cooling segment growing 40%/yr.
what_must_be_true: GPU power density continues increasing beyond air cooling capacity (Confirmed: NVIDIA H100/B200 requires liquid cooling at density, 1000W+ per GPU)
Data center operators prioritize cooling efficiency for total cost of ownership (Confirmed: cooling is 30-40% of data center operating cost)
Water scarcity regulations begin constraining data center siting (Likely: Northern Virginia, Phoenix, and other data center hubs facing water stress)
Liquid cooling technology matures for retrofit and new-build applications (Confirmed: CoolIT, ZutaCore, Vertiv all shipping at scale)
models.key_v3_context: AI GPU power density makes liquid cooling structurally necessary — not optional. The F6 data at 1.7B gallons/day water consumption is creating regulatory backlash. AI optimization of cooling systems reduces both energy (30-40%) and water (60-80%). This is the intersection of F6 energy constraint and F1 compute demand — the physical infrastructure that AI scaling requires. v2 missed data center infrastructure entirely because it falls between NAICS codes (construction, HVAC, software, utilities).

models.name: Virtual Power Plant Aggregation Platform
models.one_liner: AI platform aggregating distributed energy resources (rooftop solar, batteries, EVs, smart thermostats) into dispatchable virtual power plants.
models.macro_source: F6 Grid Bottleneck + Distributed Energy Growth
models.unit_economics: Revenue: wholesale energy market participation ($50-200/MWh during peaks), capacity payments ($50-150/kW-year), and utility program administration fees. Typical VPP: 50-500MW aggregated from 10K-100K distributed assets. Platform fee: 15-30% of energy market revenue. Build cost $5-15M. Gross margin 70-80%. FERC Order 2222 enables DER participation in wholesale markets. TAM: $5-15B US by 2030.
what_must_be_true: FERC Order 2222 implementation proceeds across all ISOs/RTOs (Confirmed: but implementation pace varies — CAISO ahead, PJM slow)
Distributed energy assets reach sufficient scale for meaningful aggregation (Confirmed: 5M+ residential solar installations, 4M+ EVs, growing)
AI dispatch optimization achieves reliable grid service delivery from distributed assets (Likely: Tesla, Sunrun, OhmConnect demonstrating in California)
Utility resistance to VPP participation diminishes (Uncertain: utilities see VPPs as competitive threat to centralized generation)
models.key_v3_context: The grid bottleneck (2,600 GW in queue) creates demand for alternatives to centralized generation. Distributed energy resources are already deployed at scale but uncoordinated. AI aggregation turns millions of small assets into dispatchable power plants. FERC Order 2222 creates the regulatory framework. Solar at $0.02-0.03/kWh (F6) makes distributed generation increasingly economic. v2 had no VPP models because this sits at the intersection of F6 energy, F1 AI optimization, and F4 capital rotation — no single NAICS sector captures it.

models.name: Gulf/MENA AI Infrastructure Services Platform
models.one_liner: Managed AI infrastructure and model deployment services for Gulf SWF-funded AI initiatives, bridging capability and ambition gap.
models.macro_source: P-031 Gulf Oil-to-AI Conversion
models.unit_economics: Managed service contracts $1-20M/yr. Saudi Humain $77B, UAE MGX $25B, Abu Dhabi 5GW campus — $100B+ committed. Gulf has capital but lacks AI engineering talent. Typical Gulf AI project needs 50-200 ML engineers unavailable locally. Service provider margin: 30-50% (premium for on-site talent in Gulf). Build cost $3-8M. TAM: $10-30B in Gulf AI services over 5 years.
what_must_be_true: Gulf SWF AI investment proceeds as committed (Likely: $100B+ already allocated, political commitment from MBS and MBZ)
Capability gap between Gulf ambition and local talent persists (Confirmed: Gulf has <5K ML engineers vs ambition requiring 50K+)
Western AI talent willing to relocate or work remotely for Gulf clients (Likely: premium compensation attracts talent, remote delivery increasingly accepted)
US export controls permit AI infrastructure deployment in Gulf states (Uncertain: Gulf falls in middle tier of chip export controls)
models.key_v3_context: P-031 identifies the Gulf as the world's fastest-moving AI investor ($100B+). But investment does not equal capability. The Gulf has a massive gap between capital deployed and engineering talent available. This creates a services opportunity for companies that can bridge the gap — similar to how consulting firms served the initial wave of enterprise cloud adoption. v2 had no MENA-specific models because sector-by-sector scanning is US-centric. The Gulf opportunity only becomes visible through the v3 geographic lens.

models.name: India AI-First Workforce Marketplace
models.one_liner: AI-native workforce marketplace matching India's 12M annual workforce entrants to global AI-economy jobs via skill assessment and training.
models.macro_source: India Demographic Dividend + Global AI Talent Shortage
models.unit_economics: Placement fee: 10-20% of first year salary (average $8-15K for AI-skilled Indian talent placed globally). Training fee: $50-200/course (employer-subsidized). 12M annual entrants, even 1% placement = 120K placements at $1-3K net/placement = $120-360M revenue. Platform build $3-8M. Gross margin 70-80%. India's IT services sector ($250B+) is the channel partner.
what_must_be_true: India's demographic dividend translates to AI-skilled workforce supply (Likely: India produces 1.5M+ STEM graduates/yr, 70% need upskilling)
Global AI talent shortage persists despite AI augmenting development itself (Likely: net demand for AI talent growing faster than supply through 2030)
Indian workforce accepts AI-native assessment and placement (Confirmed: India mobile-first, high tech adoption among young workforce)
Regulatory barriers to cross-border AI work are manageable (Uncertain: H1B uncertainty, but remote work reduces visa dependency)
models.key_v3_context: India has 1.44B people, median age 28, producing 12M workforce entrants per year (F2). The global AI economy needs millions of AI-skilled workers. India's IT services sector ($250B+) proves the cross-border talent model works. But 70% of India's workforce has an AI skills gap. The marketplace must combine TRAINING + PLACEMENT — upskill Indian talent to AI-economy standards, then place them globally. v2 had no India workforce model despite India being the world's largest talent supply.

models.name: Japan Care Economy AI Platform
models.one_liner: AI + robotics platform for Japanese elder care facilities, reducing staff-to-resident ratios from 1:3 to 1:8 via autonomous monitoring/assist.
models.macro_source: Japan Aging Crisis (Median Age 49, -900K/yr)
models.unit_economics: System price: $50-200K per facility (AI monitoring + robotic assist devices). Recurring SaaS: $2-5K/month per facility. Japan has 15K+ care facilities, 2M+ care workers needed by 2040 (vs 2.1M available today with declining population). Staff cost $30-40K/yr per care worker. Reducing from 1:3 to 1:8 ratio = $60-100K savings per facility/yr. Payback: 6-18 months. Build cost $10-20M. Gross margin: 40-50% hardware, 80% software.
what_must_be_true: Japanese elderly and families accept robotic/AI care assistance (Likely: Japan has highest cultural acceptance of robots globally, already deploying care robots)
AI monitoring reduces adverse events and meets Japanese care standards (Uncertain: regulatory approval pathway unclear for autonomous care functions)
Japanese care workforce shortage cannot be solved by immigration (Confirmed: Japan policy limits immigration, population declining 900K/yr)
Robotic assist devices mature enough for daily care tasks (Likely: Toyota, SoftBank, Panasonic all developing, government subsidizing)
models.key_v3_context: Japan is the leading indicator for aging economies (median age 49, population declining 900K/yr). By 2040, Japan needs 2M+ care workers but working-age population is shrinking. There is NO human solution — AI + robotics is the ONLY path to maintaining elder care quality. Japan already has the highest robot density and highest cultural acceptance of robotic assistance. v2 had no Japan-specific models because sector scanning is US-centric, but Japan's aging crisis is 5-10 years ahead of US/EU — solutions developed here will export globally.

models.name: EU AI Act Compliance-as-a-Service
models.one_liner: End-to-end EU AI Act compliance platform for non-EU companies entering European market: risk classification, documentation, conformity assessment.
models.macro_source: EU AI Act (F3 Regulatory Divergence)
models.unit_economics: Compliance assessment: $50-200K per AI system. Ongoing monitoring: $20-100K/yr per system. Conformity assessment prep: $100-500K per high-risk system. Aug 2026 deadline for high-risk provisions. Every US/Asian company selling AI in EU needs compliance. Estimated 50K+ AI systems requiring classification. Build cost $2-5M. Gross margin 75-85%. TAM: $3-8B EU AI compliance market by 2028.
what_must_be_true: EU AI Act enforcement proceeds with meaningful penalties (Confirmed: 2-4% global revenue penalties, enforcement bodies being established)
Non-EU companies choose compliance over EU market exit (Likely: EU is $18T GDP market, too large to abandon)
Compliance requirements are complex enough to require external help (Confirmed: 100+ pages of technical standards, risk classification is non-trivial)
Compliance platform can stay current with evolving EU interpretation (Uncertain: regulatory interpretation will evolve over 2-3 years)
models.key_v3_context: EU AI Act is the world's first comprehensive AI regulation, with enforcement beginning Aug 2026 for high-risk systems. This creates a hard deadline for compliance. Three regulatory regimes (US permissive, EU restrictive, China state-directed) mean companies operating globally need compliance infrastructure for each. The TIMING is the key: Aug 2026 deadline creates urgency NOW. v3 mapped this as a geographic regulatory divergence that creates a compliance market — v2 saw it only as a barrier, not as a market opportunity.

models.name: Cross-Border AI Regulatory Arbitrage Platform
models.one_liner: Platform helping AI companies navigate 3 regulatory regimes (US/EU/China) to optimize product deployment, data handling, and compliance cost.
models.macro_source: P-028 AI Ecosystem Bifurcation
models.unit_economics: Platform license $100-500K/yr for mid-size AI companies. Enterprise: $500K-$3M/yr. Advisory retainer $200K-$1M/yr. Every AI company selling globally must navigate diverging regulations. 3 regulatory regimes × evolving rules = persistent complexity. Build cost $3-8M. Gross margin 75-85%. TAM: $5-10B cross-border AI compliance by 2030.
what_must_be_true: Regulatory divergence persists and deepens (Confirmed: US, EU, China moving in different directions on AI regulation, no convergence expected)
AI companies prefer platform solution over internal legal teams (Likely: regulation complexity exceeds internal capacity for all but the largest companies)
Platform can track 3+ regulatory regimes in near-real-time (Uncertain: regulatory change velocity may outpace any platform)
Market is large enough for a platform vs professional services approach (Uncertain: may be a consulting market rather than a software market initially)
models.key_v3_context: P-028 identifies AI ecosystem bifurcation as the most significant geographic finding. Three distinct regulatory regimes are diverging, not converging. Every AI company that operates globally faces a compliance optimization problem: what can you deploy where, with what data, under what restrictions? This is the meta-opportunity created by geopolitical fragmentation (F3). v2 had no cross-border regulatory model because NAICS scanning is sector-specific, not regime-comparative.

models.name: LATAM AI Nearshoring Enablement Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered platform matching US companies with LATAM AI talent and manufacturing capacity for nearshored operations.
models.macro_source: P-029 Reshoring Reality Gap + LATAM Demographics
models.unit_economics: Placement fee: 15-25% first year (talent nearshoring). Manufacturing matchmaking: 1-3% of contract value. Mexico FDI $40.9B, growing. US-LATAM time zone alignment = real-time collaboration. AI talent cost: 40-60% of US equivalent. Platform build $2-5M. Gross margin 70-80%. TAM: $8-15B LATAM nearshoring services market.
what_must_be_true: US-China decoupling continues driving nearshoring to LATAM (Confirmed: Mexico FDI record $40.9B, Kearney reshoring index at -311)
LATAM AI talent pool grows fast enough to serve demand (Likely: Brazil, Mexico, Argentina produce 500K+ STEM graduates/yr)
USMCA and bilateral trade frameworks remain supportive (Uncertain: political dynamics, tariff risk under new US administration)
LATAM infrastructure supports AI-intensive nearshored work (Uncertain: variable internet/power infrastructure across LATAM)
models.key_v3_context: P-029 (reshoring reality gap) identifies record capital flowing to nearshoring but output lagging. LATAM has favorable demographics (median age 31, growing population), time zone alignment with US, and improving STEM education. The gap between reshoring capital and operational output creates a services opportunity: companies WANT to nearshore but struggle to execute. v2 had one US-LATAM model but focused on professional services — this is the broader enablement platform.

models.name: Africa/South Asia AI Compute Access Platform
models.one_liner: Platform providing affordable AI compute access to African and South Asian developers via Gulf-funded data centers and open-source models.
models.macro_source: P-031 Gulf AI + P-028 Bifurcation + Emerging Market Demographics
models.unit_economics: Compute-as-a-service at 30-50% of US cloud pricing (Gulf subsidized infrastructure + open-source models). Developer subscription $10-50/month. Enterprise tier $500-5000/month. Africa: 1.4B population, youngest continent, fastest-growing developer community. South Asia: 2B+ population, massive mobile-first market. Gulf data centers provide compute. Platform build $3-8M. Gross margin 50-65%.
what_must_be_true: Gulf data center investments in MENA serve as regional compute hubs for Africa/South Asia (Likely: geographic proximity, UAE submarine cables to East Africa and India)
Open-source models (DeepSeek, Llama) reduce the quality gap vs proprietary models enough for practical applications (Likely: P-028 bifurcation makes open-source viable for most tasks)
African/South Asian developers have sufficient demand for AI compute (Uncertain: developer communities growing but commercial AI deployment still early)
Payment infrastructure allows monetization in low-GDP markets (Uncertain: mobile money helps, but $10-50/month is significant in many markets)
models.key_v3_context: The AI ecosystem bifurcation (P-028) and Gulf AI investment (P-031) together create compute access for emerging markets that was previously impossible. Gulf data centers provide the infrastructure. Open-source models eliminate the API cost barrier. Africa and South Asia have the demographics (3.4B people, youngest populations) but lack compute access. v2 had no emerging market compute model — this only becomes visible when you combine three patterns: bifurcation, Gulf investment, and demographic dividend.

models.name: Micro-Firm AI Operating System
models.one_liner: All-in-one AI operating system for 1-5 person firms: AI employees handle ops, finance, legal, marketing, sales — human focuses on craft.
models.macro_source: Coasean Shrinkage (532K/mo new businesses)
models.unit_economics: Subscription: $99-499/month per micro-firm. 532K new business applications/month in US alone. 5.5M businesses under 5 employees. Even 2% penetration = 110K subscribers = $130-660M ARR. AI agent cost: $10-30/firm/month at current inference rates. Gross margin 85-90%. Platform build $3-8M. Replaces $50-150K/yr of admin labor that micro-firms currently either do themselves (opportunity cost) or don't do at all (lost revenue).
what_must_be_true: AI agents can reliably handle multi-domain business operations (Likely: accounting AI + legal AI + marketing AI integrated, each domain proven separately)
Micro-firm founders trust AI with business-critical operations (Uncertain: F5 psychology applies, but necessity drives adoption when no alternative exists)
532K/month business formation rate sustains (Confirmed: sustained for 48+ months, structural Coasean shrinkage not cyclical)
Platform integration is more valuable than point solutions (Likely: micro-firms need simplicity, not 8 separate AI tools)
models.key_v3_context: This is the NUMBER ONE emerging category. 532K new businesses/month is Coasean shrinkage in action — transaction costs are falling, so firm size shrinks and firm count explodes. These micro-firms need everything a 50-person company has (accounting, legal, HR, marketing, sales) but cannot afford any of it at traditional prices. AI makes a 1-person firm operationally equivalent to a 10-person firm. v2 had MC-54-001 (micro-firm OS for professional services) — this is the HORIZONTAL version for ALL micro-firms, not just professional services. The v3 economy map shows Coasean shrinkage as a cross-sector pattern, not a professional services phenomenon.

models.name: AI Workforce Orchestration Platform
models.one_liner: Enterprise platform managing hybrid human-AI teams: task routing, capability matching, performance measurement, and workforce rebalancing.
models.macro_source: AI Adoption at Scale + Workforce Transformation
models.unit_economics: Enterprise license $20-100/employee/month (for AI-managed workforce). Average enterprise: 5K-50K employees = $1.2-60M/yr per customer. Platform determines which tasks go to humans vs AI agents, routes work, measures output, identifies reskilling needs. Replaces/augments HR+operations stack. Build cost $8-15M. Gross margin 80-85%. TAM: $20-40B (intersection of HR tech + AI operations + workforce management).
what_must_be_true: Hybrid human-AI teams become the standard organizational model (Likely: already happening in coding, customer service, writing — extends to all knowledge work)
Task-level routing between human and AI is technically feasible (Likely: task decomposition + capability matching is a solved problem at simple level, complex at scale)
Enterprises adopt centralized AI workforce management rather than team-by-team decisions (Uncertain: may stay distributed initially)
AI agent capabilities are measurable and comparable to human performance (Likely: for defined tasks, AI benchmarking is increasingly precise)
models.key_v3_context: Every enterprise deploying AI at scale faces the same problem: how do you manage a workforce that is part human, part AI? Current HR and operations tools assume 100% human workers. Current AI tools assume 100% AI execution. The hybrid reality needs a new management layer. This is an EMERGING CATEGORY with no NAICS code because the hybrid human-AI workforce did not exist 2 years ago. v2 had staffing destruction models (P-027) but no models for what REPLACES traditional workforce management.

models.name: Human Premium Marketplace
models.one_liner: Verified marketplace for human-crafted services commanding 15-30% premium: artisan goods, hand-written content, human consultation, bespoke work.
models.macro_source: F5 Human Premium Signal (23% willing to pay 15-20% more)
models.unit_economics: Marketplace take rate 15-25% on premium human services. Average transaction $50-500. Verified human status via blockchain/provenance. Categories: handmade goods, human-written content, personal consultation, artisan food, custom artwork. Organic food analogy: started at $3.4B in 1997, now $63B — 18x in 25 years. Human premium could follow similar trajectory. Build cost $2-5M. Gross margin 70-80%.
what_must_be_true: Human premium demand is structural, not nostalgia (Uncertain: could be early-wave reaction that fades as AI normalizes, OR could be permanent like organic food)
Verification of 'human-made' is technically and economically feasible (Uncertain: provenance tracking for services is harder than for physical goods)
Premium is sufficient to sustain marketplace economics (Likely: 15-20% premium on $50-500 items generates sustainable unit economics)
Category grows beyond luxury/niche to meaningful market size (Uncertain: organic food took 20+ years to reach scale)
models.key_v3_context: F5 psychology reveals a counter-current to AI adoption: 23% of people willing to pay 15-20% MORE for human services. This mirrors the organic food movement — a values-based market premium created by anxiety about the dominant mode of production. As AI content and services flood every market, the scarcity value of verifiably human work increases. This is a PURE EMERGING CATEGORY created by the AI transformation itself. No NAICS code exists for 'human-premium marketplace.' v2 could not detect it because it requires the F5 psychology framework.

models.name: Second-Order Cascade Intelligence Service
models.one_liner: Analytics platform tracking and predicting second-order economic cascades (Financial->CRE->regional banks->credit) for institutional investors.
models.macro_source: Second-Order Cascade Effects (Financial Services -> CRE -> Regional Banks)
models.unit_economics: Institutional subscription: $100-500K/yr per hedge fund/PE firm. Advisory retainer: $200K-$1M/yr. The cascade: financial services AI adoption -> reduced headcount -> commercial real estate vacancy (20.1%) -> regional bank CRE exposure -> credit tightening -> second-wave business distress. Each link is measurable, predictable, tradeable. Build cost $2-5M. Gross margin 80-85%. TAM: $2-5B institutional analytics.
what_must_be_true: Second-order cascades from AI adoption are measurable before they fully propagate (Likely: CRE vacancy 20.1% is the first domino, regional bank exposure is quantifiable)
Institutional investors pay for AI-specific cascade intelligence (Likely: hedge funds and PE firms are largest consumers of alternative data)
AI can model multi-step economic cascades with useful accuracy (Uncertain: complex system dynamics are inherently hard to predict)
Cascade timing is specific enough to be actionable (Uncertain: 'sometime in 2026-2028' may not be precise enough for trading)
models.key_v3_context: The engine identified second-order cascades as a key unknown: Financial Services acceleration -> CRE vacancy -> regional bank exposure -> credit tightening. This chain is now partially confirmed (CRE vacancy 20.1%, bank exposure quantified). But no one is tracking the FULL cascade chain as a coherent system. This is the meta-opportunity: using AI to predict AI's second-order effects on the economy. v2 could not see this because it analyzed sectors independently — the cascade only becomes visible when you map the connections between sectors.

models.name: AI Agent Marketplace and Orchestration Layer
models.one_liner: Marketplace where businesses discover, deploy, and orchestrate specialized AI agents across functions — the 'app store' for AI agents.
models.macro_source: F1 AI Agent Capability + Micro-Firm Demand
models.unit_economics: Marketplace take rate: 15-30% on agent subscriptions. Average agent subscription: $50-500/month. Orchestration layer subscription: $200-2000/month per business. 532K new businesses/month need AI agents. 5.5M micro-firms are the initial market. Agent developers build for the marketplace (two-sided network effects). Build cost $5-12M. Gross margin 80-85%. TAM: $15-30B AI agent marketplace by 2030.
what_must_be_true: AI agent capabilities mature to reliable autonomous task execution (Likely: coding, customer service, data analysis agents already deployed, expanding rapidly)
Businesses prefer marketplace discovery over building custom agents (Likely: same dynamic as app stores vs custom mobile development)
Orchestration across multiple agents from different providers is technically feasible (Uncertain: interoperability standards still emerging)
Network effects create defensible marketplace position (Likely: agent reviews, usage data, and integration ecosystem create switching costs)
models.key_v3_context: AI agents are transitioning from novelty to production tool. But there is no 'app store' equivalent for AI agents — businesses must discover, evaluate, and integrate agents manually. The 532K/month new business formation (Coasean shrinkage) creates massive demand for ready-to-deploy AI agents. This is an infrastructure layer for the AI economy that has no NAICS code. v2 could not detect it because it was constructing individual AI-powered business models rather than the meta-layer where AI agents are bought and sold.

models.name: Physical-Digital Convergence Consulting
models.sector_name: AI Transformation Services for Physical Businesses (New Category)
models.one_liner: Consulting + implementation for physical businesses (manufacturing, trades, healthcare) adopting AI — bridging the 78-point implementation gap.
models.macro_source: Manufacturing 78-Point Gap (98% exploring, 20% ready)
models.unit_economics: Implementation engagement: $100K-$1M per facility. Annual retainer: $50-200K/yr for ongoing optimization. 350K US manufacturing establishments, 98% exploring AI, 20% ready = 78-point gap = 273K facilities need help. Average manufacturing facility has $5-20M revenue. Even 1% penetration = 2,730 engagements at $250K = $680M. Build cost $3-8M. Gross margin 55-65% (labor-intensive consulting). TAM: $10-20B AI implementation services for physical economy.
what_must_be_true: 78-point implementation gap is a capability problem, not a willingness problem (Confirmed: 98% exploring means willingness exists; 20% ready means capability is the bottleneck)
Third-party consulting can bridge the gap faster than in-house learning (Likely: physical businesses lack AI talent, will need external help)
AI implementation in physical environments requires domain-specific expertise (Confirmed: manufacturing AI different from office AI — sensor data, control systems, safety requirements)
Capital rotation to physical (F4) includes implementation budgets, not just hardware (Likely: VC funding for robotics/manufacturing increasingly includes implementation services)
models.key_v3_context: The 78-point manufacturing implementation gap is the largest single deployment bottleneck in the AI economy. 98% of manufacturers are exploring AI, but only 20% are ready to implement. This gap exists because AI implementation in physical environments is fundamentally different from digital — it requires understanding of manufacturing processes, sensor systems, safety protocols, and production workflows. v2 had manufacturing AI models but assumed the implementation would be self-service. The v3 economy map reveals that the IMPLEMENTATION SERVICE is itself a massive market.

lowest.name: Africa/South Asia AI Compute Access Platform

top_10_by_composite.name: AI Governance and Compliance Operating System
Grid Interconnection Consulting and Expediting Platform

construction_notes.why_v2_missed_these: v2 scanned 293 NAICS sectors bottom-up, constructing 522 models sector by sector. This approach could not detect: (1) Defense AI — crosses multiple NAICS codes and requires geopolitical context; (2) Fear economy — market created by psychology, not by sector economics; (3) Energy infrastructure services — sits between NAICS codes (construction, utilities, consulting); (4) Geographic-specific models — v2 was US-centric; (5) Emerging categories — no NAICS code exists yet; (6) Cross-sector patterns that only become visible at the economy-map level.
construction_notes.construction_discipline: Every model has concrete unit economics (not 'large TAM'). Every model cites specific force mechanisms (not 'AI disrupts X'). Every model lists testable assumptions in what_must_be_true. Scoring is calibrated against existing v3-2 rated models (MC-52-001 at 83.0 is the benchmark).
highest_conviction_gaps_filled: Defense AI (10 models): $2.72T global spend, zero v2 coverage. STRUCTURAL gap, not an oversight.
Fear Economy (7 models): $86B market created by F5 psychology. Market did not exist in v2 framing.
Micro-Firm OS (1 model, highest composite): Horizontal version of v2's professional-services-only MC-54-001.
Grid Interconnection (1 model, structural winner): 2,600 GW queue = binding constraint creating service market.
Corporate Reskilling (1 model): 39% skills obsolescence, 59% no training. $30-50B market with zero v2 models.
remaining_gaps: Agriculture AI — still underexplored, India 60% agricultural employment
Government/public sector AI — massive market, procurement friction
Transportation AI beyond defense — autonomous trucking, shipping, rail
Real estate AI beyond CRE vacancy — PropTech in distressed markets
Biotech/pharma AI — 295 FDA devices is a leading indicator of deeper healthcare AI
